Award.AwardTitle: Exploiting Control and Communications Technqiues to Establish and Maintain Network Connections for Robust and Flexible Multi-Robot Coordination

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective:
The objective of this project is to investigate a set of control and communication techniques for establishing and maintaining communication connections among multiple collaborating mobile robots, in response to varying communication conditions in practice, to ensure robust and flexible multi-robot coordination. The approach is to exploit the features of wireless communications and mobility of robots to significantly increase the coverage and reliability of communications and the chance of forming communication links among mobile robots.

Intellectual merit:
This research addresses the critical challenge in the establishment and maintenance of communication connections among collaborative mobile robots, which is imposed by unstable communication conditions and the dynamic nature of robots and environments. The intellectual merit lies in the transformative development and integration of novel distributed control and communication techniques for controlled communications, multi-robot motion, and wireless signal search under unstable communication conditions and robot/task constraints. The integrated application of these techniques will lead to robust and efficient communication networking, high-freedom task operation and exploration, and thus highly robust and flexible coordination among multiple collaborative robots.

Broader impacts:
The broader impacts include 1) facilitating numerous applications of multi-robot systems by solving the fundamental problem of establishing and maintaining robust communication connectivity among robots, and providing a foundation to various research topics based on it; 2) developing new course materials and training graduate and undergraduate students in a cross-disciplinary context; 3) providing research opportunities to high school students and to K-12 teachers and community college faculty, and encouraging students to set their career goals in engineering and science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multi-robot systems comprised of collaborative mobile robots have numerous applications, e.g. surveillance, environment monitoring, disaster rescue, space exploration, etc. Multi-robot collaborations rely on wireless communications. To establish and maintain wireless communication connections in a multi-robot system operating in a physical environment is a challenging problem, due to the unstable signal propagation condition and dynamic nature of the robots and environment. Aiming at providing a robust and adaptive solution, this project addressed this problem with a synergistic consideration of control and communications.

Exploiting the mobility of mobile robots, distributed multi-robot control was explored to facilitate the control of robot teams at different sizes to carry out dynamic tasks and adapt to conditions of environments and wireless signal propagation. Two intelligent control approaches based on locally perceived wireless link quality were developed. The fuzzy control approach takes advantage of the adaptability of fuzzy inference to uncertainties of inputs, and thus enables a multi-robot system to adapt to the fluctuation of signal strengths in physical environments. The reinforcement learning neural network control approach takes advantage of the adaptability of artificial neural network and learning process to unknown input-output relationship, and thus enables a multi-robot system to adapt to the unknown communication condition in an unknown environment. Moreover, it was recognized that reliable control of multi-robot systems requires a comprehensive consideration of the involved constraints both on individual robots and imposed by the interactions among robots. A constrained optimal control approach was derived. It combines the underlying robot model and involved constraints, including the communication constraint, into a constrained optimal dynamic model, and allows each robot to make optimal motion decisions according to the constraints and states of itself and nearby robots and objects.

Exploiting the features of wireless communications, the techniques to reliably detect the boundary nodes in a low-density network and search for outside interference signal sources were developed, which facilitate initially separate clusters of robots to form a larger-size connected network. A dual-range communication scheme was explored, where each wireless communication node can work within either a shorter range for data transmission and receiving or a longer range for signal sensing. The signal sensing range was exploited to help multiple mobile robots work flexibly in a large area while maintaining connections. Moreover, a more accurate method was developed to estimate the direction of a received signal, combining the algorithms of multiple signal classification and particle filtering. Based on the estimated signal direction and received signal strength, a robot can move towards a signal source to form a communication connection. It provides a foundation for the higher level multi-robot motion control approaches to form and recover communication connections from sparsely and randomly located mobile robots.

In addition, a multi-robot experimental system was created, consisting of ten mobile robots with programmed onboard capabilities of control and wireless communications. An enhanced mobile robot localization approach was developed, which provides a reliable and inexpensive indoor robot localization solution. This system not only provided a testbed to verify the developed approaches but also provides a significant experimental platform for a wider range of research and education in mobile robotics and multi-robot systems.
